Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story:
I stood at the curb, trash bin in hand, glancing at the half-full container. My neighbor, Mrs. Lee, always reminded me to wait until the bin was full before dragging it out, so we wouldn’t clutter the sidewalk. But tomorrow was trash pickup, and I’d be gone all day, unable to bring it out later. I hesitated, feeling the weight of her expectation to be considerate with our shared space.

Later, at the polling station, I joined the line to vote. An official announced, “If your last name is A–M, please move to the new line.” My last name fit, but the new line was barely moving, while the original one sped along. The official’s voice was firm—follow instructions, keep the process fair. I glanced at the others, some already shifting, some staying put.

I felt torn, the same way I had with the trash bin. As a neighbor, I wanted to respect boundaries and not inconvenience others. As a voter, I was expected to follow directions, even if it meant waiting longer. The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I stood there, caught between what I owed to my neighbor and my duty as a citizen.
